newsitem.title: LEBANON: Beirut takes attack warning seriously - official.
newsitem.headline: Beirut takes attack warning seriously - official.

text.p: Beirut is taking seriously a warning by Israel's proxy militia in south Lebanon of a big Israeli military operation if there is an upsurge of violence in the south, a senior foreign ministry official said on Thursday.
"Lebanon is taking these grave threats seriously," the official told Reuters. "We are surprised that they come when security conditions in south Lebanon are relatively stable."

General Antoine Lahd, commander of the South Lebanon Army (SLA), issued the warning on Wednesday while urging Lebanon to reconsider Israel's "Lebanon first" proposal for a conditional withdrawal of its troops from south Lebanon.

Israel said in July it was ready to pull out under a deal to be negotiated with Syria, if Syrian troops also left Lebanon and if the Lebanese army could guarantee Israel's security against cross-border guerrilla attacks.
Both Syria and Lebanon rejected the offer.

Lahd said Lebanon faced the possibility of widescale Israeli retaliation if pro-Iranian Hizbollah (Party of God) guerrillas stepped up their attacks on Israeli troops occupying a 15-km (nine-mile) south Lebanon border strip.
Israel launched a bloody 17-day blitz against Lebanon in April after tit-for-tat bombardments of civilian areas by the two sides.
Beirut newspapers on Thursday quoted parliament Speaker Nabih Berri, Lebanon's top Shi'ite Moslem official, as warning of possible Israeli attacks before the U.S. presidential election in November.
"Israel might benefit from the no-decision situation in the United States before the election to get the green light for launching an offensive against Lebanon," Berri said.

The foreign ministry official, who asked not to be identified, said Lebanon insisted on implementation of U.N. Security Council resolution 425 from 1978 calling for immediate and unconditional Israeli withdrawal.
He said Foreign Minister Faris Bouez would raise the issue with his Syrian counterpart Farouq al-Shara during a visit to Syria on Thursday ahead of a meeting of Arab foreign ministers in Cairo.
Damascus is the main power broker in Lebanon with 35,000 troops stationed throughout most of the country.
